journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Non-smooth dynamical analysis and experimental validation of the cable-suspended parallel manipulator

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical & Electrical Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, PR China
2Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore

author-notes.corresp: Xing-Guo Shao, School of Mechanical & Electrical Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, PR China. Email: sxgyjq@126.com

abstract.p: The cable-suspended parallel manipulator replaces the rigid links of traditional parallel robot. The unilateral property of the cable complicates the dynamic analysis of such manipulator and further induces difficulty in control problem. The set-valued tension law is proposed to model the unilateral constraint of the cable, and the dynamics of cable-suspended parallel manipulator is analyzed in the framework of non-smooth dynamics. The resulting non-smooth dynamics model consists of a set of differential–algebraic equations with inequality constraints. Its solution is found by the Moreau midpoint method. An experimental setup was established to verify and validate the effectiveness and accuracy of non-smooth dynamics. And the simulation results generally agree with the experimental results, which demonstrate that the non-smooth dynamics is effective and reasonable for the dynamic analysis of the cable-suspended parallel manipulator. The results of this article deeply reveal the dynamics of the cable-suspended parallel manipulator, and may be used to design more accurate controller for its trajectory control.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The cable-suspended parallel manipulator (CSPM) supports a platform (or end-effector) by multiple spatially arranged cables driven by winches, which are generally mounted on fixed base.1 The CSPM has large load-carrying capacity, since the load on the platform can be shared by multiple cables.2 Moreover, both the translational motion and the orientation of the load can be controlled by the CSPM. And the load is not prone to sway, because the CSPMs have higher stiff than conventional cranes.3 The above merits of the CSPM make it suitable for lifting and positioning large heavy load in many industrial applications, such as manufacturing, construction, clean-up of disaster sites, aircraft paint stripping, and shipbuilding.2 The application of the CSPM can also be found in coal mining industry, where a sinking winch mechanism suspending a platform is used to dig a vertical shaft. As shown in Figure 1, the sinking winch mechanism consists of four winches, four cables, a derrick, and a platform. The platform supplies the workspace for workers, and also the base for machines. It is lowered down (or lifted up) by reeling out (or reeling in) four cables on the winches. Therefore, the sinking winch mechanism can be viewed as a four-CSPM. Figure 1.
Sinking winch mechanism.

Compared with traditional parallel manipulator, the CSPM replaces the rigid links with cables. The unilateral property of the cable (i.e. the cable can only pull the object, but not push it) complexes the dynamic analysis, further inducing the control problem (such as maintenance of the positive tension in cables and accurate trajectory control of the platform).4 The dynamics problem of the CSPM has been addressed in previous works.5–8 These works pointed out the unilateral property of the cables (i.e. the tensions in cables must be non-negative), and the dynamics models were formulated by differential equations and constraint equations. The constraint equations generally expressed the constraints of the cables as follows: li C=li AB and λi≥0, where li C is the length of ith cable, li AB the distance from the suspended point to the attachment point of the ith cable, and λi the tension in ith cable. These constraint equations meant that the cables should not be slack during the motion of the manipulator. However, the cables could be slack (for this case, the constraint equations of the cables should be expressed by li C≥li AB and λi=0 during the motion of the CSPMs if the inertial force of the platform is considered,2 because the CSPMs are generally under-constrained. Thus, the tension states of cables may be alternate between the tautness and slackness during the motion of the CSPMs.

Note that the non-smooth dynamics theory was developed to specially treat the unilateral constraint/contact, impact, and friction in mechanical system.9–15 Actually, the previous works on the dynamics of the CSPMs partly implicated the idea of the non-smooth dynamics; however, they did not analyze and model the dynamics of CSPMs in the framework of non-smooth dynamics explicitly. The non-smooth dynamics theory has been applied for many mechanical systems with unilateral contacts and friction.16–20 However, to our best knowledge, its application to the CSPM has not been reported yet in the literature.

In this article, the dynamics of the CSPM is modeled in the framework of non-smooth dynamics. The unilateral constraints of cables are taken into consideration in the dynamics model. An experimental setup was established based on the prototype of sinking winch mechanism. The experimental setup is taken as an example for the numerical simulation study. And a comparison between the simulation and experimental results is also presented. The rest of this article is arranged as follows. The architecture and coordinate system of the CSPM is described in the second section. And its non-smooth dynamics model is formulated in the third section. “Numerical solutions” section describes the Moreau midpoint method and the numerical algorithm to solve the non-smooth dynamics model. “Simulation and experiment studies” section presents the simulation and experimental results. And some conclusions are drawn in the final section.

sec.title: Architecture and coordinate system
sec.p:
Figure 2 exhibits the architecture and coordinate system of the CSPM. The upper part is the base, on which the winches are fixed, while the lower part is the platform. One upper end of the cable is winded on the winch, and the lower end connects the platform. The posture of the platform is changed by rolling in (or rolling out) cables through the winches. These cables are indexed, respectively, as 1,2,…,n counterclockwise, which are assembled into an index set IC={1,2,…,n}. Points Ai,i∈IC are the tangent points between the cables and the drums of the winches (only one winch is shown in Figure 2 for simplicity). And Bi,i∈IC are the attachment points connecting the cables and the platform. An inertial frame oxyz is located at the base, while the local frame OXYZ has the origin at the mass center of the platform. Thus, the position of the platform is represented by the Cartesian coordinates of origin O (rO=[x,y,z]T) in the inertial frame; the orientation of the platform is given by Cardan angles α (roll), β (pitch), and ϕ (yaw) defined at the local frame. The Cartesian coordinates of tangent points Ai,i∈IC in the inertial frame are denoted by ri A=[xAi,yAi,zAi]T, and the attachment points Bi,i∈IC in local frame by ri B=[XBi,YBi,ZBi]T. Figure 2.
Architecture and coordinates system.

sec.title: Non-smooth dynamics model
sec.p: The system which we investigate consists of the cables and the platform, while the dynamics of the winches is not considered. For simplicity of dynamics analysis, the cables are assumed to be massless, undamped, and perfectly stiff, i.e. the stiffness is positive infinite (or zero) if the cable is pulled (or pushed). This stiff characteristic reflects the unilateral constraint of a cable. In what follows, we first formulate the set-valued tension law to model the unilateral constraints of the cables, and then give the equations of motion of the system by Lagrange multiplier method, and finally, obtain the non-smooth dynamics model of the system by combining the equations of motion with the set-valued tension law.

sec.title: Set-valued tension law
sec.p:
We borrow the idea of set-valued normal contact law,21,22 and modify it to the set-valued tension law to suit the case of the unilateral constraints of the cables. Referring to Figure 2, we define the length difference of the ith cable as (1)gLi(q,t)=li C-li AB,i∈IC, so as to describe the tension state of cable i at time instant t, where q=[x,y,z,α,β,φ]T is the posture of the platform, li C the length of the ith cable, li AB the distance of points Ai and Bi. It is obvious that the cable is slack if gLi>0, and taut if gLi=0, so that the inequality gLi≥0 always holds. Let λi be the tension of cable i. One sees that λi=0 if the cable is slack, and λi≥0 if the cable is taut. Therefore, the tension of a cable λi and the length difference gLi satisfy the following relationship (2)λi≥0,gLi≥0,gLi·λi=0,i∈IC, which is shown in Figure 3. It shows a set-valued map (λi is set-valued if gLi=0, and vice versa). Equation (2) models the unilateral constraints of the cables, and is called as the set-valued tension law. Figure 3.
Set-valued tension law.
For a compact expression of the set-valued tension law, we define gL=[gL1,gL2,…,gLn]T and λ=[λ1,λ2,…,λn]T, respectively, and abbreviate (2) as (3)0≤gL⊥λ≥0

sec.title: Equations of motion
sec.p: In this section, we use the Lagrange multiplier method to derive the equations of motion of the system. We assume that the cables are massless, undamped, and perfectly stiff. Thus, the kinetic and potential energies of the system lie with the platform only. Since the platform generally moves slowly, the aerial resistance to the platform is so trivial that it can be ignored. Therefore, the generalized force is zero. If the kinetic energy, potential energy, and generalized force are introduced into the Lagrange equation,23 the equations of motion of system are obtained as (4)M(q,t)u·-h(u,q,t)-W(q,t)·λ=0 where M is the mass matrix, u=q· the generalized velocity, u·=q·· the generalized acceleration, h the external and gyroscopic forces applied on the system, and W a matrix which contains generalized force directions of all cables Wi as (5)W=[w1,w2,…,wn]
where Wi is defined as (6)wi(q,t)= (∂gLi∂q )T
The detailed expressions of M and h are given in Appendix 2.

sec.title: Non-smooth dynamics model of the system
sec.p: The final non-smooth dynamics model of the system is obtained by combining the Lagrange’s equation (4) with the set-valued tension law (3) as follows (7)M(q,t)u·-h(u,q,t)=W(q,t)·λwith 0≤gL⊥λ≥0.

sec.title: Numerical solutions
sec.p: The non-smooth dynamics model (7) of the system is actually a set of differential–algebraic equations with the inequality constraints. At present, there are four types of numerical methods available to solve the non-smooth dynamical system, i.e. smoothing method, switch model method, event-driven integration method, and time-stepping method.21 The smoothing method is simple but yields stiff differential equations which are numerically expensive to solve. The switch model method partly solves this problem but the logical structure of its model becomes very complex if the mechanical system has multiple frictional contacts (or unilateral constraints). Both the event-driving integration and the time-stepping methods can deal with many contacts in a rigorous way, which is transforming the contact problem into linear complementarity problem (LCP).24–26 However, time-stepping method becomes more advantageous than event-driving method if many contacts are involved in the mechanical system.21,27

In this study, a time-stepping method is selected to solve the non-smooth dynamics model. Among the time-stepping methods, the Moreau midpoint method is one of the most popular methods,19 and thus, this method is used in this study. We first present the time discretization of non-smooth dynamics model, and then describe the Moreau midpoint method based on LCP.

sec.title: Time discretization to equations of motion
sec.p: Multiplying equation (4) with the Lebesgue measure dt yields (8)M(q,t)u·dt-h(u,q,t)dt-W(q,t)·λdt=0 or more briefly (9)M·du-h·dt-W·λdt=0 where du=u··dt is the measure for velocity. Integrating equation (9) over a small finite time interval Δt yields (10)∫ΔtM·du-∫Δth·dt-∫ΔtW·λdt=0 where the integration terms are approximated by (11) {∫ΔtM·du≈M·Δu∫Δth·dt≈h·Δt∫ΔtW·λdt≈Wλ where Λ represents the percussion. Substitution of equation (11) into equation (10) yields (12)M·Δu-h·Δt-Wλ=0
Equation (12) gives the equations of motion expressed at velocity level.

sec.title: Time discretization to set-valued tension law
sec.p: The derivative of length difference gL with respect to time t is (13)γ=dgL(q,t)dt=WT·u+w~ where WT=∂gL/∂q and w~=∂gL/∂t. Thus, the set-valued tension law at velocity level is given as (14)0≤γ⊥λ≥0
In each time-step, the velocity difference Δu and percussion Λ can be solved from equations (12) and (14) with the Moreau midpoint method.

sec.title: Moreau midpoint method
sec.p: At the beginning of a time-step tA, the position and velocity of the system are known as qA and uA, respectively. At the midpoint of the time-step tM=tA+0.5·Δt, the corresponding position is estimated as (15)qM=qA+0.5·uA·Δt which is subsequently used to calculate a set IT= {i|gLi(qM,tM)≤0,i∈IC }, and the set contains all indices of taut cables.

At the midpoint, equation (12) is rewritten as (16)MM·(uE-uA)-hM·Δt-WM·λ=0 where Δu=(uE-uA), and uE is the velocity at the end of the time-step tE=tA+Δt, MM, hM, and WM are the matrices evaluated at the midpoint as (17) {MM=M(qM,tM)hM=h(uA,qM,tM)WM=mat{wi(qM,tM)},i∈IT

At the beginning and the end of the time-step, equation (13) becomes, respectively, as (18)γA=WM T·uA+w~M (19)γE=WM T·uE+w~M where w~M is a vector evaluated at the midpoint as (20)w~M=col {∂gLi(qM,tM)∂t },i∈IT
Subtraction of equation (18) from (19) yields uE-uA=WM -T(γE-γA), which is substituted into equation (16) to get (21)γE=(WM TMM -1WM)·λ+(WM TMM -1hMΔt+γA)
At the end of the time-step, the set-valued tension law is given as (22)0≤γE⊥λ≥0
Equations (21) and (22) form an LCP, from which γE and Λ can be solved with an LCP solver based on Lemke’s algorithm.28 Then, substituting Λ into equation (16) gives (23)uE=MM -1·WMλ+MM -1·hM·Δt+uA
Thus, the generalized position at the end of time-step is obtained as (24)qE=qM+0.5·uE·Δt
The tensions of cables are found from percussion Λ as (25)λ=λΔt
The procedure for solving the non-smooth dynamics model of the CSPM is given in Appendix 3.

sec.title: Simulation and experiment studies
sec.p: In this section, we take the simulation and experimental study to verify and validate the accuracy and effectiveness of the non-smooth dynamics theory by comparing the simulation and experimental results. We first describe the measurement method of the state variables obtained from numerical simulation, and then present the simulation and experiment results; finally, we demonstrate the accuracy and effectiveness of the non-smooth dynamics theory.

sec.title: Measuring of state variables
sec.p:
Referring to the prototype of sinking winch mechanism, an experimental setup was established at China University of Mining and Technology (shown in Figure 4). One obtained from “Numerical solutions” section that the state variables of the experimental setup include the tensions of four cables, the position, and orientation of the platform. Figure 5 shows the sensors mounted on the experimental setup for measuring the state variables. To obtain the tensions of cables, four tension sensors are fixed on the platform, and the top end of sensors are connected with cables. The orientation of the platform is detected by a micro-inertia measurement unit fixed on the platform, and the Cardan angles (roll, pitch, and yaw) of the platform can be directly obtained. The position of the platform is estimated as follows: (a) fix three cable-displacement sensors on the derrick; (b) aggregate the ends of three cables into a point P, the Cartesian coordinates of P in inertial frame represent the position of the platform; (c) measure the lengths of three cables Lk,(k=1,2,3) by the displacement sensors; (d) with the known coordinate of fix points Ck,(k=1,2,3), solve the nonlinear equations |CkP|=Lk,(j=1,2,3) to get the coordinates of point P. Figure 4.
Experimental setup. Figure 5.
Sensors mounted on the experimental setup.

sec.title: Simulation and experimental results
sec.p: In what follows, we take the experimental setup as an example to simulate its dynamic behavior under the given motion of cables. The four cables are rolled in at the speed as follows (26) {v1=0.1+0.08sin[0.2πt-(π/2)]v2=0.1+0.08sin[0.2πt-(2π/3)]v3=0.1+0.08sin[0.2πt-(5π/6)]v4=0.1+0.08sin[0.2πt-(3π/4)]

Referring to Figure 2, the geometrical and physical parameters of the experimental setup are given as follows: the index set of cables is IC={1,2,3,4}; the Cartesian coordinates of Ai in inertial frame oxyz and Bi in local frame OXYZ are listed in Tables 1 and 2, respectively; the mass of the platform mP=80kg, and its inertial tensor is IP=[4.6700.041-0.0920.0414.681-0.015-0.092-0.0157.146]kg·m2 Table 1.
Coordinates of Ai in inertial frame.
A1 A2 A3 A4
x −0.310 −0.310 0.310 0.310
y 0.240 −0.240 −0.240 0.240
z 0 0 0 0
Table 2.
Coordinates of Bi in local frame.
B1 B2 B3 B4
X −0.327 −0.327 0.327 0.327
Y 0.250 −0.250 −0.250 0.250
Z 0.230 0.230 0.230 0.230

The initial parameters for the simulation are given as follows: all cables have the equal initial length li=3.666m, and the initial position of is given as qA=[0,0,-3.896,0,0,0]T m; the initial velocity of the platform is uA=[0,0,0.02,0,0,0]T m/s. The simulation starts at t0=0 s, and stops at tF=20 s, the time-step Δt is set as 0.01 s. The experiment was carried out in accordance with the parameters in the simulation. And the simulation and experimental results are presented in Figures 6 and 7. The simulation results are drawn by red dashed lines, while the solid blue lines show the experimental results. Figure 6.
Tensions of cables: (a) tension of cable 1; (b) tension of cable 2; (c) tension of cable 3; and (d) tension of cable 4. Figure 7.
Position and orientation of the platform: (a) position of the platform in x-axis; (b) position of the platform in y-axis; (c) position of the platform in z-axis; (d) roll of the platform; (e) pitch of the platform; and (f) yaw of the platform.

sec.title: Analysis and discussion
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the tensions of four cables. Both the simulation and experimental results show that the tension states of cables alternate between tautness and slackness during the motion of the mechanism. However, there also exist errors between simulation and experimental results, especially in the process that includes the tension alternation in cables. Simulation results show the tension mutation at time instants (such as 8.93, 10.18, and 19.16 s); however, the experimental results reveal the downy variation of the tensions. That is because the simulation results ignore the mass, elasticity, and the damping of the cables, while the experimental results include these properties of the cables. The error between the simulation and experimental results also comes from the following factors: (a) error of numerical calculation for simulation model and (b) error between the real cable speeds with the given speeds.

Figure 7 presents the position and orientation of the platform. As can be seen, the simulation results generally agree with the experimental results. The errors between these two results arise from the following factors: (a) the simulation results ignore the properties of the cables, while the experimental results include them; (b) the geometrical and physical parameters supplied to the simulation model have errors with the real mechanical system; and (c) measuring errors come from the sensors. As shown in Figure 7, it should be noted that the simulation results of yaw have larger fluctuation than the experimental results. That is because the simulation results ignore the torsional stiffness of the cables, while the experimental results reveal the effect of the torsional stiffness.

It can be seen from Figures 6 and 7 that the simulation results generally agree with the experiment results. If the property of cable is incorporated into the non-smooth dynamic model, the simulation results would better agree with the experimental results.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article investigates the non-smooth dynamics of the CSPM. We propose the set-valued tension law to model the unilateral constraints of the cables. Lagrange multiplier method is used to derive the equations of motion, which is complemented with the set-valued tension law to formulate the non-smooth dynamics model of the system. And the model is solved with Moreau midpoint method based on LCP.

An experimental setup was established based on the prototype of sinking winch mechanism (a four-CSPM). Take the experimental setup as an example, the simulation and experiment studies were performed. Both the simulation and experimental results show the alternation of the tensions in cables. And the simulation results generally agree with the experimental results, which demonstrate the effectiveness and accuracy of the non-smooth dynamics for modeling the dynamics of the CSPM. The errors between the simulation and experimental results mainly arise from the factor that simulation model ignores the properties of cables, while the experimental results include them. The dynamics analysis considering the properties of cables in the framework of non-smooth dynamics will be our future work.
The results of this article deeply reveal the dynamics of the CSPM, and can be used to design more accurate controller for the trajectory control of the CSPM.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work is supported by National Science Foundation for Young Scientists of China (Grant Number 51005233), Special Financial Grant from the China Postdoctoral Science Foundation (Grant Number 201104582) and Technology Research and Guidance Program of China National Coal Association (Grant Number MTKJ2011-299).

def.p: length difference of li C and li AB
distance of points Ai and Bi

sec.p: The mass matrix is expressed as (27)M=[mE300RTIR] where m is the mass of the platform, I the inertial tensor of the platform, E3∈ℝ3×3 a unit matrix, and R the transformation matrix between angular velocity vector of the platform ω=[ωX,ωY,ωZ]T and the time derivative of Cardan angles ϖ=[α·,β·,φ·]T, i.e. ω=Rϖ, and R is defined as (28)R=[Cβ·CφSφ0-Cβ·SφCφ0Sβ01]

The gyroscopic force h is formulated as (29)h=[h1 Th2 T]T in which (30)h1=[00-m·g]T (31)h2=[012ϖT· (∂RT∂β·I·R+RT·I·∂R∂β )·ϖ12ϖT· (∂RT∂φ·I·R+RT·I·∂R∂φ )·ϖ] - (∂RT∂t·I·R+RT·I·∂R∂t )·ϖ where g=9.8m/s2 is the gravitational acceleration.
%function
[T,QE,UE,F]=MMA(t0,tF,Δt,qA,uA,mP,IP)
% t0 and tF are the beginning and end time of the simulation
% Specify the geometrical variables for sinking winch mechanism
xA=col{xAi},i∈IC; % coordinates of Ai
yA=col{yAi},i∈IC; in inertial frame
zA=col{zAi},i∈IC;
XB=col{XBi},i∈IC;% coordinates of Bi
YB=col{YBi},i∈IC; in local frame
ZB=col{ZBi},i∈IC;
vd=col{vi},i∈IC; % speed of cables
L0 V=col{Li0 V},i∈IC; % initial lengths of cables at t0
for s=1:n
% formulate the LCP
C=WM TMM -1WM;d=WM TMM -1hMΔt+γA;
γE=Cλ+d; 0≤γE⊥λ≥0;
% solve the LCP by calling function
[γE,λ,err]=Robust_Lemke(C,d); uE=MM -1·WMλ+MM -1·hM·Δt+uA;
qE=qM+uE·Δt/2;
λ=λ/Δt;
% collect the tension of cables into a vector f
for j=1:nT
end
for k=1:nS
end
% collect the results into matrixes
tE=tA+Δt; T=[T,tE]
QE=[QE,qE];UE=[UE,uE];
% update the variables
tA=tE; qA=qE; uA=uE;
end
end
